nodes.text: An efficient binary-search fault injection method leveraging (approximate) monotonicity of ML error propagation can identify safety-critical bits and measure resilience in safety-critical machine learning systems with far lower cost than exhaustive FI
Safety-critical ML systems (e.g., autonomous vehicles) are vulnerable to hardware transient faults (soft errors) that can cause silent data corruptions (SDCs) and violate safety requirements

Exhaustive fault injection (flipping every bit) finds critical bits but is prohibitively expensive because time grows linearly with number of bits; random FI cannot reliably discover clustered critical bits

Many common ML computations and their compositions exhibit monotonicity or approximate monotonicity (convolution/MatMul, ReLu, pooling, batch norm, SoftMax, data transforms), so error propagation functions (EP) are often monotonic or approximately monotonic

When EP is (approximately) monotonic, larger input deviations (from higher-order bit flips) produce larger output deviations and are more likely to cause SDCs, implying an SDC boundary in bit significance
BinFI: a binary-search-like FI algorithm that converts operator outputs to binary, separates 0- and 1-bits, and searches for the SDC-boundary by bisecting bit significance per operator output element

Fault model and injection mapping: single-fault-per-execution in processor data path (pipeline registers and ALUs), map faults to operator outputs in TensorFlow graph, emulate single-bit flips (sufficient to approximate multi-bit effects)

Traditional heavy-weight protections (replication, instruction duplication) incur high cost and latency unsuitable for real-time safety-critical ML (e.g., AVs) motivating selective protection guided by identifying critical bits
Random FI has poor coverage for discovering clustered critical bits even with many trials; exhaustive FI is the only comprehensive baseline but is slow and costly
Implementation: extended open-source TensorFI to support DNN operators and added BinFI modes (binary, exhaustive, random); injections performed at operator output values in TensorFlow

Evaluation setup: ran BinFI, exhaustive FI and random FI across 8 ML models and 6 datasets (including driving frames and traffic signs), using 32-bit fixed-point representation and 10 inputs per benchmark for tractability
BinFI identified 99.56% of safety-critical bits with 99.63% precision across evaluated benchmarks, substantially outperforming random FI with the same number of trials
Knowing critical bits enables selective, low-cost protection strategies (dynamic fault tolerance, voltage scaling, focused defenses) and guides security/hardening efforts against fault-based attacks

BinFI reduces number of FI trials to approximately 20% of exhaustive FI (about 5x speedup) and produces overall SDC probability estimates that closely match exhaustive FI (low deviation), while overhead scales logarithmically with bit width

Limitations and inaccuracy sources: EP functions are sometimes only approximately monotonic so BinFI can miss a small fraction of critical bits (<0.5% reported); not 100% coverage necessitates caution if exhaustive guarantees are required

Conclusion: BinFI is a practical first-step tool for low-cost identification of safety-critical bits in ML inference, enabling selective protection tradeoffs; future work includes other ML frameworks, more safety domains and selective protection schemes
